metadata.case_name: Sri Rama Vilas Service P Ltd. v. C. Chandrasekaran & Ors.

facts.text: Regional Transport Authority, Thanjavur called for applications for grant of one stage carriage permit between Mannargudi and Nagapattinam (34 miles).
Four applicants: appellant (Sri Rama Vilas Service P Ltd.), Raman & Raman P Ltd., Balasubrahmanya Udayar, respondent No.1 (C. Chandrasekaran).
RTA granted permit to appellant as it got highest marks.
Order challenged by three rejected applicants before State Transport Appellate Tribunal, Madras.

Appellate Tribunal reassessed merits, assigned marks: appellant and Raman & Raman 4 each, others 3 1/2 and 3 1/4; rejected appellant and Raman due to appellant's monopoly over first 18 miles and Raman's near monopoly over remaining 16 miles; granted permit to respondent No.1.
Appellant filed writ petition No. 25 of 1959 before Madras High Court; Srinivasan J. issued writ of certiorari quashing Tribunal's order for failing to consider relevant evidence.
Respondent No.1 appealed under Letters Patent (Writ Appeal No. 20 of 1962); Division Bench reversed Srinivasan J., dismissed writ petition.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.
Over first 18 miles (sector 1), appellant runs 7 buses, no other buses (monopolist).
Over second 16 miles (sector 2), Raman & Raman runs 9 buses, two others run 2 buses (near monopolist).
Parallel railway between Tiruvarur and Nagapattinam.

legal_issues.text: Whether consideration of monopoly status of applicants is relevant under s.47(1)(a) of Motor Vehicles Act in granting permits.
Whether Appellate Tribunal failed to consider relevant factors (competition between monopolist and near-monopolist, parallel railway) warranting certiorari under Art.226.
Scope of High Court's jurisdiction under Art.226 in reviewing quasi-judicial orders of transport authorities for adequacy of reasons.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellate Tribunal failed to consider relevant evidence, influenced by abstract concept of monopoly; ignored competition between appellant (monopolist) and Raman (near-monopolist), and parallel railway competition.
Administrative directions under s.43A discouraging monopoly have no legal force and cannot bind authorities.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Ms. Raman & Raman Ltd. v. State of Madras; s.43A Motor Vehicles Act

respondent_arguments.text: Appellate Tribunal considered relevant factors including railway; other valid reasons support decision; High Court should not interfere under Art.226 merely for not marshalling all reasons.

court_reasoning.text: Monopoly consideration is relevant under s.47(1)(a) as absence of competition may lead to complacence and neglect public interest; not irrelevant even if in administrative directions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appropriate authority can enquire if applicant's service would be efficient; monopoly factor valid.

court_reasoning.text: Theoretical competition between monopolist (first sector) and near-monopolist (second sector) impractical for through passengers; not effective.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Passenger prefers continuous journey; hypothetical competition invalid.

court_reasoning.text: High Court under Art.226 not appellate; should not issue certiorari solely for inadequate reasons if relevant factors considered and no perversity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tribunal's order referred to monopoly and railway; proper assessment.

court_reasoning.text: Encouraging smaller operators and discouraging monopoly consistent with public interest under s.47(1)(a).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Division Bench correctly reversed single Judge.

holdings.text: Monopoly is relevant consideration under s.47(1)(a) Motor Vehicles Act.
No grounds for certiorari as Tribunal considered relevant factors; High Court should not interfere lightly.
Art.226 jurisdiction not appellate; certiorari not for mere inadequacy of reasons.

precedents_cited.case_name: R.K. Ayyaswami Gounder v. Ms. Soudambigai Motor Service, Dharampura & Others
precedents_cited.relevance: Monopoly consideration not influenced by irrelevant fact.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ms. Raman & Raman Ltd. v. The State of Madras & Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Administrative directions under s.43A have no legal force.

precedents_cited.case_name: R. v. Agricultural Land Tribunal for the Eastern Province of England, Ex parte Grant
precedents_cited.relevance: Certiorari issued where decision based on irrelevant grounds; not applicable here.

statutes_cited.name: Motor Vehicles Act, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: Public interest paramount in granting permits; monopoly relevant; administrative directions not binding.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court jurisdiction for certiorari limited; not appellate review.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upheld Division Bench's reversal of single Judge's writ of certiorari, affirmed Appellate Tribunal's grant of permit to respondent No.1.

key_quotes.text: "Absence of any competition from another bus-operator on the route is likely to develop a feeling of complacence in the monopolist and that is a factor which the appropriate authority can certainly take into account."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "High Court is not exercising the jurisdiction of an Appellate Court... decisions rendered by them on all questions of fact should not be interfered with under Art.226 unless well-recognised tests satisfied."
key_quotes.speaker: court
